item.latestTitle: Extending Government Funding and Delivering Emergency Assistance Act

latestAction.text: Referred to the Committee on Appropriations, and in addition to the Committees on the Budget, and Ways and Means, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned.

item.latestTitle: Extending Government Funding and Delivering Emergency Assistance Act
A bill to temporarily extend the public debt limit until December 16, 2022.

latestAction.text: Read the second time. Placed on Senate Legislative Calendar under General Orders. Calendar No. 138.

On passage Passed by the Yeas and Nays: 219 - 212 (Roll no. 310). (text: CR H5526)
Passed/agreed to in House: On passage Passed by the Yeas and Nays: 219 - 212 (Roll no. 310).(text: CR H5526)
On motion to commit Failed by the Yeas and Nays: 211 - 219 (Roll no. 309).
Considered as unfinished business. (consideration: CR H5547-5549)
UNFINISHED BUSINESS - The Chair announced that the unfinished business was the question on the motion to commit S. 1301, which was debated earlier and on which further proceedings had been postponed.

POSTPONED PROCEEDINGS - At the conclusion of debate on S. 1301, the Chair put the question on the motion to commit and by voice vote announced the noes had prevailed. Mr. Brady demanded the yeas and nays and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
The previous question on the motion to commit was ordered pursuant to clause 2(b) of rule XIX.
Mr. Brady moved to commit to the Committee on Ways and Means. (text: CR H5534)
The previous question was ordered without objection.
DEBATE - The House proceeded with one hour of debate on S. 1301.

Rule provides for consideration of S. 1301 with 1 hour of general debate. Previous question shall be considered as ordered without intervening motions. Measure will be considered read. A specified amendment is in order.
Considered under the provisions of rule H. Res. 688. (consideration: CR H5526-5534)
Rule H. Res. 688 passed House.

Rules Committee Resolution H. Res. 688 Reported to House. Rule provides for consideration of S. 1301 with 1 hour of general debate. Previous question shall be considered as ordered without intervening motions. Measure will be considered read. A specified amendment is in order.
Held at the desk.
Received in the House.
Message on Senate action sent to the House.
Passed Senate without amendment by Voice Vote. (consideration: CR S5224; text: CR S5224)
Passed/agreed to in Senate: Passed Senate without amendment by Voice Vote.(consideration: CR S5224; text: CR S5224)
Placed on Senate Legislative Calendar under General Orders. Calendar No. 75.

Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions Committee

item.text: Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions. Ordered to be reported without amendment favorably.

item.name: Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions Committee

item.text: Read twice and referred to the Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions.
Introduced in Senate

Promoting Physical Activity for Americans Act

This bill requires the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) to continue issuing at least every 10 years physical-activity guidelines based on the most current scientific and medical knowledge.

HHS must also publish updated reports that detail evidence-based practices and highlight continuing physical-activity issues between iterations of the guidelines.
item.name: Introduced in Senate

item.text:
Promoting Physical Activity for Americans Act

This bill requires the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) to continue issuing at least every 10 years physical-activity guidelines based on the most current scientific and medical knowledge.

HHS must also publish updated reports that detail evidence-based practices and highlight continuing physical-activity issues between iterations of the guidelines.
item.name: Reported to Senate

item.text:
Promoting Physical Activity for Americans Act

This bill requires the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) to continue issuing at least every 10 years physical-activity guidelines based on the most current scientific and medical knowledge.

HHS must also publish updated reports that detail evidence-based practices and highlight continuing physical-activity issues between iterations of the guidelines.
item.name: Passed Senate

item.text: This bill suspends the public debt limit through December 16, 2022. The bill also requires the limit to be adjusted on December 17, 2022, to accommodate obligations issued during the suspension period.
item.name: Passed House

item.text: This bill increases the public debt limit by $480 billion.
item.name: Senate agreed to House amendment

item.text: This bill increases the public debt limit by $480 billion.

item.text: This bill increases the public debt limit by $480 billion.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
